question: How do the interactions between Rose and Brindle Bill—specifically Rose's disbelief of Brindle Bill—illustrate the roles of belief and skepticism in shaping the dynamics of their characters throughout the novel?
gold_answer: Rose did not believe Brindle Bill, illustrating the role of skepticism in their character dynamics.
llm_answer:
Rose’s instant, scornful refusal to credit anything Brindle Bill says—“I would not believe him on oath”—sets her up as the story’s lone consistent skeptic.  That skepticism is the polar opposite of Simon’s ready credulity: he swallows Bill’s tale of the dead sisters because it is convenient, while Rose rejects it because she smells a lie.  The contrast fixes the moral poles of the novel: belief is the currency of the swindle, skepticism the only defense against it.

Yet Rose’s disbelief is powerless once she has relinquished control.  She doubts Bill, but she has promised Simon that “she would let him manage the business,” and money “thrust upon” her is finally irresistible.  Her skepticism is therefore sincere but ineffectual: it highlights the difference between seeing a lie and being able to act on that knowledge.  Brindle Bill, for his part, never expects to be believed on the merits; he trades on the eagerness of others to believe.  Rose’s scorn does not wound him—he simply winks again and keeps raising the price—because the game is not about persuading the skeptical woman but about exploiting the greedy husband.

Thus the running disbelief Rose voices becomes a measure of how completely the men around her are willing to be duped.  Each time she says, “I would not believe him,” the reader is reminded that the swindle proceeds only because Simon chooses belief over his wife’s judgment.  Skepticism is the novel’s lonely, unheard conscience; belief—especially the self-interested kind—is the engine of the plot.
